definitions.definition: used to say that something has been removed or become separated

examples.text: He's had his beard shaved off.
Take your coat off.
The label must have fallen off.
Don't leave the toothpaste with the top off.
The water is off.
Make sure the TV is off.

definitions.definition: down or away from a place; at a distance in space or time

examples.text: I called him but he ran off.
I gave up riding after I fell off.
Sarah's off in India somewhere.
I must be off *(= I must leave)* soon.
Summer's not far off now.
A solution is still some way off.
**Off you go! **Enjoy yourselves!
She's off today.
I've got three days off next week.
How many days did you **take off**?
I need some **time off**.
They're off *(= the race has begun)*.
shoes with $20 off
All shirts have/are 10 per cent off.

definitions.definition: no longer going to happen; cancelled

examples.text: The wedding is off.

definitions.definition: no longer available or being served

examples.text: Sorry, the duck is off.

definitions.definition: behind or at the sides of the stage in a theatre
to be in a better or worse situation

examples.text: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.
We can't be any worse off than we are already.

definitions.definition: to have a particular amount of something

examples.text: How are we off for coffee *(= how much do we have)*?

definitions.definition: used to say how much money somebody has

examples.text: Families will be better off under the new law *(= will have more money)*.
They are both comfortably off *(= have enough money to be able to buy what they want without worrying too much about the cost)*.

definitions.definition: from time to time; now and again

examples.text: It rained on and off all day.

wordOrigin: Old English, originally a variant of of (which combined the senses of ‘of’ and ‘off’).
